name: US NIH to investigate allergic reactions after mRNA-based vaccines
introduction: In the USA, the National Institutes of Health (NIH) is to initiate a Phase II trial to investigate the causes of certain allergic reactions to mRNA-based vaccines.
content:
In the USA, the National Institutes of Health (NIH) is to initiate a Phase II trial to investigate the causes of certain allergic reactions to mRNA-based vaccines.

The trial follows reports that a small number of people given Moderna's (Nasdaq: MRNA) mRNA-1273 or Pfizer (NYSE: PFE) and BioNTech's (Nasdaq: BNTX) Comirnaty COVID-19 vaccines had severe allergic reactions.

Anthony Fauci, director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, said the goal of the study would be to provide guidance for people who are “highly allergic or have a mast cell disorder" about the risks and benefits associated with the coronavirus vaccines.

The study comes as regulators in the UK and Europe have concluded another coronavirus vaccine, Vaxzevria, from AstraZeneca (LSE: AZN) and Oxford University, could carry a very low risk of a rare, severe blood clot.

Several European countries have advised offering the vaccine to over-30s or older demographics only, while UK Health Secretary Matt Hancock described the level of risk as being comparable to that from a long-haul flight.

mRNA-based vaccines

In a statement, the NIH explained that most of the rare, severe allergic reactions to mRNA-based vaccines have occurred in people with a history of allergies. 

The number of cases is very low, and a large number of the people who had a reaction had previously experienced a life-threatening anaphylactic event.

Dr Fauci said: “The public understandably has been concerned about reports of rare, severe allergic reactions to the Moderna and Pfizer-BioNTech COVID-19 vaccines.”

“However, for most people, the benefits of COVID-19 vaccination far outweigh the risks,” he added.

The study will enroll 3,400 adults ages 18 to 69 years at up to 35 academic allergy-research centers around the USA, with around 60% of study participants having had a severe allergic reaction in the past, or a diagnosis of a mast cell disorder.
